captions.text:
This episode of DNews is brought to you by
Toyota’s Hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, Leave
your mark. Toyota, let’s go places.

It's 2015, Hollywood prophecy says we should
have flying cars, and though we don't have
those… how about hydrogen cars?

Fueling your car with hydrogen is weird. Hydrogen,
number 1 on the periodic table. It's a powerful

combustible element, it blew up the Hindenburg
after all! But it's also part of water, and

carbohydrates, and so many other things in
nature. The thing is… hydrogen is a lot

of things, and IN a lot of things, because
it's a super simple element; one proton, one

electron and it makes up SEVENTY-FIVE PERCENT
of the universe. Yeah, three quarters of everything

is hydrogen. Hydrogen is used for food processing,
petroleum refining and in a variety of industrial

applications. The U.S. already creates more
than 9 million metric tons of hydrogen annually!

So I say again, fueling your car with hydrogen
is weird, but not THAT weird.

You've probably heard of hydrogen fuel cells,
they've been around for a while. They were

first invented in 1839. They use oxygen and
hydrogen to power a car with no moving parts,

and only emit clean water vapor when burned.
And according to many car companies, 2015

might be the year the rubber meets the road
for hydrogen as a fuel. When you think of

creating hydrogen, you probably think of this[a]
but 95 percent of America's hydrogen is produced

using natural gas steam reformation. Factories
use high temperatures and pressures to break

the natural gas into hydrogen (YAY!) and carbon
oxides (BOO!). You can also make it using

electrolysis -- essentially running electricity
through water to split the hydrogen from the

oxygen! Two great things! But something has
to GENERATE that electricity, and in the U.S.,

that's usually coal power. But if we used
wind, or solar -- then we'd be onto something.

Once it's made, it has to be cooled and stored,
which uses MORE fossil fuel energy; and then

you have to ship it to pumping stations using
trucks and trains… you get it. The HYDROGEN

is great, but we suck at making it and moving
it around.

For now we're stuck making hydrogen using
fossil fuels, which might not be ideal, but

that could all change once hydrogen vehicles
get on the roads! Why buy a hydrogen car if

there's nowhere to fill it up! The government
and private companies are partnering to get

fuel stations out there… California has
a goal in place to have more than 15 percent

of all cars in the state be zero-emissions
vehicles by 2025 -- and to hit that goal they've

pledged 200 million dollars to build 100 more
fueling stations before then. There are already

10, though I don't imagine they're very busy
since there aren't too many cars on the road
yet, but that'll change soon too.

In tandem with this momentum, a bunch of auto
companies have pledged to release hydrogen

fuel cell cars this year, and with 100 more
stations coming too, filling them up should

be a cinch! According to research from the
University of California Davis, those 100

stations should be able to make fuel cell
vehicles cost-competitive with gasoline!

We'd like to take a second and give a shout
out to Toyota for supporting DNews. They were

at CES this week and released their patents
for new fuel-cell technology, and revealed

THEIR fuel cell car to the world, the Mirai.
They’re hoping these royalty-free patents

will spurn a hydrogen-fuel-based future and
spent the last decade reducing the cost of
fuel cell production 95 percent.

Have you ever seen a hydrogen fuel station?
Would you want a
hydrogen car?

comments.author: Unknownuser151

comments.text:
I'm confused, Hydrogen to me has always sounded 'decades away'. There are 
so many problems associated with them. Mainly with storage of the gas into 
some other form that's easier to store, such as in metal lattices. The 
other problems would be resources; there's a lot of platinum needed for 
these fuel cells, which with asteroid mining (decades into the future as 
well) would quickly become unsustainable as the demand for platinum 
increases- hence the price of these cars.
Elon musk says "The sooner we give up on hydrogen the better. This will be 
super obvious when time goes by." I however disagree- in part, Hydrogen 
just needs a way to be stored efficiently and that would be a massive 
breakthrough. However i think that breakthrough will happen far too long in 
the future...
its a promising fuel, but rolling them out this early on when they run on a 
tank, with limited range just seems odd to me. Unless say, the battery is 
bigger, enough for a 400km drive. with a quick refill.
The Toyota Mirai also looks terrible. It's going to be another Prius, 
ridiculed by terrible aesthetics and reviews from petrolheads and car 
enthusiasts such as myself, however the hybrids of this generation are 
looking pretty good. Li-Ion batteries and the whole lot. And they're coming 
out to be very efficient.
I'm not saying that this hydrogen era won't catch on, but It's definitely 
going to be slow. Real slow. I wouldn't buy a car that's only the 
first-step when there's more developed technologies such as Tesla's cars, a 
hybrid or just a standard ICE. However is still flawed, the charging times 
are too slow; its just the way they present the electric car is just so 
right.
Anyone agree that Fuel Cells are currently far from being commercially 
viable? Especially with the points in this video about being fossil-fuel 
reliant?﻿

comments.author: Dercio Silveira

comments.text:
Making hydrogen on the go is an easy way to fuel your car. The problem 
remains of REGULATING the hydrogen to fuel injectors...but this can be done 
though a computer system using pulse technology by pulsing the electricity 
to produce the hydrogen you need. I manufacture it all the time using five 
small plates and a 12 volt battery. The plumbing for the car, has to be 
aluminum tubing and very well sealed, Running the hydrogen through a 
regulator using a computer program can regulate the hydrogen like gas is 
regulated through your computer system.ALSO the timing on the car has to be 
changed, because hydrogen runs hotter and more efficient than gas. You can 
mix hydrogen with gas to save you money, but in a period of time, your 
cylinder walls will become corroded by the hydrogen mixing back with the 
air to form water. So, the best hydrogen car is the fuel cell car, like 
they have. Using hydrogen gas is a pain in the butt. using hydrogen cells 
works a lot better.﻿

comments.author: ObsidianReflexion

comments.text:
Yes hydrogen comes currently comes from fossil fuels.  It's stupid to build 
a very expensive hydrogen infrastructure for pricey cars (last prices I saw 
were in the $250,000 range). We already have a great electricity 
infrastructure.  Elementary thermodynamic considerations show that a 
hydrogen economy is about as feasible as a perpetual motion machine. 
Hydrogen is not an energy source but an energy carrier, and when produced 
renewably, it is an energy carrier to the second degree, with electricity 
being the energy carrier to the first degree. As such, it greatly elongates 
the chain of energy transformations required to deliver a desired service 
from a primary source of energy. There will undoubtedly be applications in 
which hydrogen may be essential, but they will be limited because the 
services it delivers will come at a substantial energy premium.  So no, I 
don't want a hydrogen car.  A nicely styled cheaper model from Tesla will 
do nicely in 5 years. ﻿

Hope it won't become the future, as producing+using H2 in a fuel cell 
wastes 2-2,5x more energy than charging batteries.
Also, Hydrogen is only made by a few producers, so its price can easily be 
controlled via manipulating its supply.
This whole hype about Hydrogen is really just a scam to get ppl buy the 
car, making them dependent on Hydrogen fuel.
Meanwhile, electric cars are safer, more efficient, and can even be charged 
at home, for free (by using solar panels) ;)
The best - and easiest - thing to do is to *not* buy a Hydrogen car, 
avoiding dependency, explosions, and energy wasting.

comments.author: ScubaShneve

comments.text:
+ScubaShneve _Battery swapping stations_ (done in 90s, for $60-80) and *sponge 
batteries* make your argument invalid.
Gas explodes if its concentration in air is 1,6-7,4%, while H2 explodes 
between 4-75%, so it's much more dangerous.
The efficiency of the *fuel cell* itself is around 50%, which could 
theoretically be raised to 85% (by utilizing waste heat),
but this makes it even more expensive, and it would still only mean about 
70% overall efficiency (compared to 90-95%).
However, the overall efficiency of the Mirai is reported to be only 25%, so 
the best fuel cell would raise it to about 40%.

You see, H2 is only made by a few producers, so its price could easily be

Production/use of H2 wastes 50-60% of the energy, but charging batteries

In the end, a electric car is safer, more efficient, and one can even 
charge it at home, for free! (by solar panels) ;)

comments.author: sin8800

comments.text:
+sin8800 The only thing that's incredible about it is how incredibly 
wasteful fuel cells are compared to batteries.
If we were to use electrolysis to produce Hydrogen, and use it in fuel 
cells, we would waste more than half of the energy.
Production/use of H2 wastes 50-60% of the energy, but charging batteries 
only wastes 5-10%, and H2 is even explosive!
In the end, an electric car is safer, more efficient, and one can even 
charge them at home, for free! (by solar panels) ;)
The best (and easiest) thing to do is to *not* buy a Hydrogen car, avoiding 
explosions, dependency, and wasting energy.
comments.author: sztellanora

comments.text:
There are already ways around the fossil fuel usage. One of which is to 
simply connect the pumps to a water supply and an electrical grid and 
perform on-location electrolysis. The increased demand for electricity 
would then help fund the growing renewable energy market. Hydrogen fuel 
cells are the best!﻿
comments.author: Crick1952

comments.text:
+Crick1952 Actually, Hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (FCV) are the worst option 
we have, with their 25% overall efficiency.
(ICE cars have 30%, Battery EVs have 80-90%). Demand for electricity would 
raise demand for cheapest source (coal).
If we produce Hydrogen via electrolysis for fuel cells, it's a waste of 
energy (compared to simply charging BEVs).
Producing it via Natural gas reforming isn't sustainable, and we are 
already running out of options to get Hydrogen.
But the biggest problem is the extremely low efficiency of fuel cells 
(about 50%). Hydrogen as a fuel makes no sense.
comments.author: sztellanora

comments.author: Michael Scott

comments.text:
+pGxMaTRiCkz According to reports, the Mirai has about 25% efficiency 
overall (compared to the 30% of ICE cars, and the 80-90% of electric cars). 
The biggest problem is that fuel cells ultimately have a very low 
efficiency (about 50%).
This could be raised by cogeneration, where the waste heat is utilized - to 
reach an efficiency of 85% (40% overall).
That, however, is still about the half of Battery electric cars, so if 
Hydrogen is generated by electrolysis, it's just wasteful.
If we were to use the same energy to power Battery EVs, we could go 2x as 
far. Hydrogen economy makes no sense.

comments.text:
+Eru Ilúvatar Who said anything about agreeing with this. I didn't say 
anything because this guy has a habit of digging his own ditch while 
explaining things. :D People can draw their own conclusions.
(any true information is good information, whatever you believe in)

I'm pro solar. Hydrogen can wait until we can make it cleanly.

P.S. get used to People being wrong on a internet ;) http://xkcd.com/386/
comments.author: Miloš Radovanović

comments.text:
+Miloš Radovanović Don't get fooled by the hype; it's a scam to get ppl buy 
the car, making them Hydrogen junkies.
Thing is, Hydrogen is only made by a few producers, so its price could 
easily be controlled by manipulating the supply.
Production/use of H2 wastes 50-60% of energy, but charging batteries only 
wastes 5-10%, and Hydrogen is explosive!
Meanwhile, an electric car is safer, more effective, and one can even 
charge them at home, for free! (via solar panels) =)
The best and easiest thing to do is to *not* buy a Hydrogen car, avoiding 
dependency, explosions, and energy wasting.

comments.author: Arvin Razavi

comments.text:
I wonder if a methane fueled car is viable... If it is, I suggest the fuel 
be made by anerobic digestion, rather than mined by fracking, as digested 
methane is carbon neutral.﻿
comments.author: Ben Crispe

comments.text:
+Ben Crispe Yes it is; Methane could be produced biologically, and it has 
an ERoEI of about 4:1, so it *is* viable.
Note1: It's much more viable than corn ethanol, which is estimated to have 
an ERoEI of 0,8-1,2 (so it's quite useless).
Note2: The ERoEI of Oil produced today is around 10:1 on a global average, 
and it's falling (we dig up the easier first).
comments.author: Eru Ilúvatar

comments.text: What are the benefits of fuel cell power over today's electric cars?﻿
comments.author: Abraxian Absolution

comments.text:
+Abraxian Absolution No, it's not, as I actually reported the losses due to 
electricity distribution and charging together under the name of "charging 
battery". But I'll break it down for you:
FCV: Electricity produced (100%), electrolysis in situ (-20%), compression 
in situ (-6%), fuel cell (-36%). Energy remaining: 38%.
BEV: Electricity produced (100%), electricity distribution (-6%), charging 
battery (5%). Energy remaining: 89%.
Source: [Patrick Mazza and Roel Hammerschlag. 2004. "Wind-to-wheel energy 
assessment"]
As you can see, in the case of BEVs, only a little amount of energy is lost 
by distributing electricity, but in the case of FCVs, a lot of energy is 
lost, mainly because the fuel cell has a very low efficiency (about 50%). 
This is what really makes Hydrogen a weak candidate for fuel.
comments.author: Eru Ilúvatar

comments.text:
+Eru Ilúvatar It seems extremely biased to compare the production+use 
losses of hydrogen calls to just the charging loss of electric.
That said, I feel like the efficiency of fuel cells would have to be 
extraordinary to be worth while compared to the diverse options for 
producing electricity and the flexibility that an electric vehicle 
infrastructure would allow.
comments.author: Abraxian Absolution

comments.text:
+Abraxian Absolution *Nothing. Battery EVs are better than Fuel cell cars 
in just about everything*
Production+use of Hydrogen wastes 62% of the energy, but charging a battery 
only wastes 10%, and H2 is explosive!
Plus, Hydrogen is really only made by a few producers, so its price could 
easily be controlled by manipulating its supply.
Meanwhile, Battery EVs are safe, more efficient, and one can even charge 
them at home, for free! (via solar panels) ;)
This hype behind Hydrogen is really just a scam to fool ppl into buying the 
car, turning them into Hydrogen junkies.
